subject: Re: [junit] Reporting historical test results
msgSnippet: Paul - Thanks for the reply.  Unfortunately, we are already doing that. We run a nightlybuild with tests.  It copies the previous results to a backup-reports
messageBody:
Paul -

Thanks for the reply. Unfortunately, we are already doing that.

We run a nightlybuild with tests. It copies the previous results to a backup-reports directory, cleans the reports directory, and then creates the current results html files. Then, we send out an e-mail to the team, with the links to the various reports (for different 'chunks' of code), both current and previous.

Every morning, I am opening those reports and copying the highest level data (from the summary section -> #tests, #failures, #errors) into an excel spreadsheet.

Currently, we are trying to get our testing back under control - many iterations of allowing people to say their stories were complete without appropriate - or even working - tests. Additionally, in the past, we have found that we have a velocity treshhold - after which our testing goes downhill. So, we have a need to maintain this historical information, over the life of the project.

I am looking for a way to automate this. What I'm thinking of is:
when the reporting functionality totals the summary numbers, it could also output to another file type (ideally, straight into an excel spreadsheet; minimally, into a file that can be used as a data source for a spreadsheet) a configurable data set: date, time, #tests, #failures, #errors, #time.

Dianne

-------------- Original message --------------




Dianne Doss asked


Is there an automated way to output the summary data (#tests,
#errors, #failures) from my JUnit Report to an external file
(possibly xls, or a file accessible by spreadsheet) in order to
maintain a history of our results?

In the ideal world, there would never be any errors or failures, but
the point of the testing is to make us confident in making code
changes. We run a nightlybuild regression, so the next morning I
can see if I missed anything (sometimes the failures are well
removed from the actual class that was changed).

So, we would like to be able to record historical data of the
fluctuations. In the past, manually, we have found that the
errors/failures go up when we get above a certain velocity.

Thanks for any insight that can be provided.

Dianne Doss


Dear Doss,

If you are generating JUnit Report through Ant, definitely you
should write one build.xml file. Before generating new report, why not you
take copy of the previous report. In Ant API contains copy tag and move
tag. So
first step you take a back up using Copy/ Move tag.
Second step you clear your old report using delete tag.
Third step create report folder again.
Finally you generate new report.



Paul Domnic J.
